S6.T1.table:
Method Compression Rate IID Test Accuracy (%) Non-IID Test Accuracy (%)
Comfetch 90% 76.53 75.29
Comfetch 75% 82.85 81.89
Comfetch 50% 84.42 83.59

references: Cost Complexity.  Note that any Hℓsuperscript𝐻ℓH^{\ell} bijectively corresponds to a hash function hℓ:d→c:superscriptℎℓ→𝑑𝑐h^{\ell}:d\rightarrow c which is representable as a length d𝑑d vector, so it is cheaper to store/transmit hℓsuperscriptℎℓh^{\ell}. Hence, in practice, the central server will transmit {(hℓ,Hiℓ​Wtℓ)}ℓ=1Lsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptℎℓsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑖ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡ℓℓ1𝐿\{(h^{\ell},H_{i}^{\ell}W_{t}^{\ell})\}_{\ell=1}^{L}, for a total local memory and transmission cost of 𝒪​((c+1)​d)𝒪𝑐1𝑑\mathcal{O}\bigl{(}(c+1)d\bigr{)}, which is far less than the usual O​(d2)𝑂superscript𝑑2O(d^{2}) cost of transmission and storage.

Cost Complexity. 
Each gtℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑡ℓg_{t}^{\ell} costs 𝒪​(c​d)𝒪𝑐𝑑\mathcal{O}(cd) to store and transmit, which is a strong improvement over the usual uplink complexity of 𝒪​(d2)𝒪superscript𝑑2\mathcal{O}(d^{2}) and even cheaper than the sketched storage cost of 𝒪​((c+1)​d)𝒪𝑐1𝑑\mathcal{O}((c+1)d).
Remark. The client will never directly compute giℓ∈ℝd×dsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑖ℓsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑑g_{i}^{\ell}\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d}. The purpose of equation equation 2 is to illustrate the gradient calculation, but we first take care to show this derivative is well-defined. Assuming ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is differentiable with respect to any weight, we only need to prove that ∂Rℓ​W∂Hℓ​Wsuperscript𝑅ℓ𝑊superscript𝐻ℓ𝑊\frac{\partial{R^{\ell}W}}{\partial H^{\ell}W} is computable, which is indeed the case due to the structure Hℓsuperscript𝐻ℓH^{\ell}. For any count sketch matrix H​ℝ𝐻ℝH\mathbb{R} and vector x𝑥x, if xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} is bucketed by hash function hjsubscriptℎ𝑗h_{j}, we have that [H⊤​H​x]i=Hj​i⋅[H​x]jsubscriptdelimited-[]superscript𝐻top𝐻𝑥𝑖⋅subscript𝐻𝑗𝑖subscriptdelimited-[]𝐻𝑥𝑗[H^{\top}Hx]_{i}=H_{ji}\cdot[Hx]_{j}, therefore, the partial derivative ∂Rℓ​W∂Hℓ​Wsuperscript𝑅ℓ𝑊superscript𝐻ℓ𝑊\frac{\partial{R^{\ell}W}}{\partial H^{\ell}W} is well-defined. In practice, the client will use an autograd-like library.

In general, Comfetch models are competitive against uncompressed FedAvg training in CIFAR10/100 training. CIFAR-10 model performance is presented in Table 1 and and Figures 2 and 3. For iid settings, 50% sketched compression results in a test accuracy drop off of <2%absentpercent2<2\%, while 75% compression results in decreased accuracy of <4%absentpercent4<4\%. We begin to notice a significant decline at 90%percent9090\% compression, which appears to be a general threshold across all experiments. Non-iid training appears to be slightly more challenging, but nonetheless, our Comfetch models mimic the performance of un-sketched models with minimal dropoff for compression rates up to 75%percent7575\%.

CIFAR-100 training, displayed in Table 2 and the bottom series of Figures 2 and 3, is far more challenging. However, our models still display competitive performance against non-sketched training for models with up to 75%percent7575\%, regardless of iid or non-iid training.

The Count Sketch data structure contains a collection of k𝑘k pairwise-independent hashing maps hi:[d]→[c]:subscriptℎ𝑖→delimited-[]𝑑delimited-[]𝑐h_{i}:[d]\rightarrow[c] for i∈[k]𝑖delimited-[]𝑘i\in[k], each of which is paired with a sign map si:[d]→{±1}:subscript𝑠𝑖→delimited-[]𝑑plus-or-minus1s_{i}:[d]\rightarrow\{\pm 1\}, for i∈[k]𝑖delimited-[]𝑘i\in[k]. Each hash function/sign map pair is used to project a d𝑑d-dimensional vector x𝑥x into c𝑐c-dimensional space, which we refer to as a sketch. Furthermore, we refer to c𝑐c as the sketching length and k𝑘k as the number of the sketches. Each of the k𝑘k sketches is representable as a linear transformation Hi​x∈ℝcsubscript𝐻𝑖𝑥superscriptℝ𝑐H_{i}x\in\mathbb{R}^{c} for i∈[k]𝑖delimited-[]𝑘i\in[k], where Hi∈ℝc×dsubscript𝐻𝑖superscriptℝ𝑐𝑑H_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{c\times d} is referred to as a Count Sketch matrix. To “unsketch” or restore a sketch back to d𝑑d-dimensional space, we simply multiply by the transpose of Hisubscript𝐻𝑖H_{i}, i.e., x^i=Hi⊤​Hi​x∈ℝdsubscript^𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑖topsubscript𝐻𝑖𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑\hat{x}_{i}=H_{i}^{\top}H_{i}x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, where we use the hat notation to specifically indicate that x^isubscript^𝑥𝑖\hat{x}_{i} is merely an approximation of x𝑥x. The final approximation x^^𝑥\hat{x} of x𝑥x is determined coordinate-wise as (x^)j=median1≤i≤k​{x^i}i=1ksubscript^𝑥𝑗1𝑖𝑘mediansuperscriptsubscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖𝑖1𝑘(\hat{x})_{j}=\underset{1\leq i\leq k}{\textrm{median}}\{\hat{x}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{k} for j∈[d]𝑗delimited-[]𝑑j\in[d].

As detailed in the previous section, each sketch has a matrix representation which we will now make explicit. Let h:[d]→[c]:ℎ→delimited-[]𝑑delimited-[]𝑐h:[d]\rightarrow[c] and s:[d]→{±1}:𝑠→delimited-[]𝑑plus-or-minus1s:[d]\rightarrow\{\pm 1\} be a hash function/sign pair. The associated count sketch matrix H𝐻H is representable as the following c×d𝑐𝑑c\times d matrix transformation: fixing i∈[c]𝑖delimited-[]𝑐i\in[c] and j∈[d]𝑗delimited-[]𝑑j\in[d], we have that (H)i​j=s​(i)subscript𝐻𝑖𝑗𝑠𝑖(H)_{ij}=s(i) if h​(j)=iℎ𝑗𝑖h(j)=i for j∈[d]𝑗delimited-[]𝑑j\in[d] and 0 otherwise.

We note that k𝑘k corresponds to the number of independent sketches, which is required theoretically to achieve a guarantee on approximating Wtℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡ℓW_{t}^{\ell}, but in practice, we observe in Section 6 that one sketch is sufficient for model convergence. Also note that any Hiℓsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑖ℓH_{i}^{\ell} bijectively corresponds to a hash function hiℓ:d→c:superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖ℓ→𝑑𝑐h_{i}^{\ell}:d\rightarrow c which is representable as a length d𝑑d vector. Hence, in practice, the central server will transmit {(hiℓ,Hiℓ​Wtℓ)}i=1ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑖ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡ℓ𝑖1𝑘\{(h_{i}^{\ell},H_{i}^{\ell}W_{t}^{\ell})\}_{i=1}^{k}, for a total local memory and transmission cost of 𝒪​((k​c+1)​d)𝒪𝑘𝑐1𝑑\mathcal{O}\bigl{(}(kc+1)d\bigr{)}, which in the one-sketch (k=1𝑘1k=1) case is less than the O​(d2)𝑂superscript𝑑2O(d^{2}) cost of transmitting the full weight.

In this section, we present additional data in Table 3 and Figure 5 for language tasks not included in the main paper. The results demonstrate that our Comfetch preserves accuracy while reducing the size of weights in gates of the LSTM layer by different ratios. We maintain a high test accuracy while reducing the number of parameters from 9607 to 2439. We exclude embedding parameters from the overall parameter counts as they serve as inputs and can be pre-trained.

In Table 4, we conduct a simple study examining how Comfetch compression affects single (unfederated) client training when ResNet-9 is used to train over CIFAR-10 over 25 epochs. We additionally conduct random pruning of a non-sketched model to mimic compression. Fixed random pruning to achieve the same compression amount outputs worse models. It is important to note that pruning works well for pre-trained models, but this study demonstrates the ineffectiveness of one-time pruning prior to training. Figure 2 demonstrates the training and test curves.

S6.T2.table:
Method Compression Rate IID Test Accuracy (%) Non-IID Test Accuracy (%)
Comfetch 90% 43.80 42.52
Comfetch 75% 52.25 50.21
Comfetch 50% 54.76 52.89
No Compression 0% 57.16 55.21

The final approximation x^^𝑥\hat{x} of x𝑥x is determined coordinate-wise as (x^)j=median1≤i≤k​{x^i}i=1ksubscript^𝑥𝑗1𝑖𝑘mediansuperscriptsubscriptsubscript^𝑥𝑖𝑖1𝑘(\hat{x})_{j}=\underset{1\leq i\leq k}{\textrm{median}}\{\hat{x}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{k} for j∈[d]𝑗delimited-[]𝑑j\in[d].

As detailed in the previous section, each sketch has a matrix representation which we will now make explicit. Let h:[d]→[c]:ℎ→delimited-[]𝑑delimited-[]𝑐h:[d]\rightarrow[c] and s:[d]→{±1}:𝑠→delimited-[]𝑑plus-or-minus1s:[d]\rightarrow\{\pm 1\} be a hash function/sign pair. The associated count sketch matrix H𝐻H is representable as the following c×d𝑐𝑑c\times d matrix transformation: fixing i∈[c]𝑖delimited-[]𝑐i\in[c] and j∈[d]𝑗delimited-[]𝑑j\in[d], we have that (H)i​j=s​(i)subscript𝐻𝑖𝑗𝑠𝑖(H)_{ij}=s(i) if h​(j)=iℎ𝑗𝑖h(j)=i for j∈[d]𝑗delimited-[]𝑑j\in[d] and 0 otherwise.

We note that k𝑘k corresponds to the number of independent sketches, which is required theoretically to achieve a guarantee on approximating Wtℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡ℓW_{t}^{\ell}, but in practice, we observe in Section 6 that one sketch is sufficient for model convergence. Also note that any Hiℓsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑖ℓH_{i}^{\ell} bijectively corresponds to a hash function hiℓ:d→c:superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖ℓ→𝑑𝑐h_{i}^{\ell}:d\rightarrow c which is representable as a length d𝑑d vector. Hence, in practice, the central server will transmit {(hiℓ,Hiℓ​Wtℓ)}i=1ksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑖ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑖ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝑡ℓ𝑖1𝑘\{(h_{i}^{\ell},H_{i}^{\ell}W_{t}^{\ell})\}_{i=1}^{k}, for a total local memory and transmission cost of 𝒪​((k​c+1)​d)𝒪𝑘𝑐1𝑑\mathcal{O}\bigl{(}(kc+1)d\bigr{)}, which in the one-sketch (k=1𝑘1k=1) case is less than the O​(d2)𝑂superscript𝑑2O(d^{2}) cost of transmitting the full weight.

In this section, we present additional data in Table 3 and Figure 5 for language tasks not included in the main paper. The results demonstrate that our Comfetch preserves accuracy while reducing the size of weights in gates of the LSTM layer by different ratios. We maintain a high test accuracy while reducing the number of parameters from 9607 to 2439. We exclude embedding parameters from the overall parameter counts as they serve as inputs and can be pre-trained.

In Table 4, we conduct a simple study examining how Comfetch compression affects single (unfederated) client training when ResNet-9 is used to train over CIFAR-10 over 25 epochs. We additionally conduct random pruning of a non-sketched model to mimic compression. Fixed random pruning to achieve the same compression amount outputs worse models. It is important to note that pruning works well for pre-trained models, but this study demonstrates the ineffectiveness of one-time pruning prior to training. Figure 2 demonstrates the training and test curves.
